details.title: Commentary: failure-rate functions for doubly-truncated random variables
details.standardTitle: Commentary: failure-rate functions for doubly-truncated random variables

p: Rebecca A. Betensky is an Associate Professor of Biostatistics at Harvard School of Public Health. She received the Ph.D. in 1992 in Statistics from Stanford University, and the A.B. in 1987 from Harvard College. Her publications include statistical methodology, as well as collaborative medical research.

authors.affiliation: Dept. of Biostat., Harvard Sch. of Public Health, Boston, MA, USA
authors.name: R.A. Betensky

p: Emily C. Martin is a doctoral student in the Department of Biostatistics, Harvard School of Public Health. She received the M.S. in 1984 in Electrical Engineering from University of Illinois at Urbana-Champaign and the B.S. in Electrical Engineering from Cornell University.

authors.affiliation: Dept. of Biostat., Harvard Sch. of Public Health, Boston, MA, USA
authors.name: E.C. Martin

details.abstract: Navarro and Ruiz (see ibid., vol.45, p.685-90, 1996) express the nonparametric maximum likelihood estimator (NPMLE) of the distribution of a failure-time random variable as a function of the NPMLE of generalized failure-rate functions. These generalized failure-rate functions are equal to the probability density functions of a doubly-truncated failure-time random variable at the endpoints of the truncating interval. Readers can infer from this paper that this simple estimator can be applied to a doubly-truncated sample of failure times. This commentary explains why that estimator does not apply to the general setting in which the observed failure times are doubly-truncated with subject-specific truncating intervals. A doubly-truncated sample of times to brain tumor progression illustrates the deviation of that estimator from the NPMLE for these data.

citations.title: Commentary: failure-rate functions for doubly-truncated random variables

links.abstract: The failure rate function is generalized for doubly-truncated random variables. This generalized function is used to characterize the distribution function and to obtain the properties that any function must have to be a generalized failure rate function, both for continuous and discrete random variables. From the theoretical results are constructed nonparametric estimators of the Kaplan-Meier type and cumulative-hazard type.

context.text:
Reference [1]takes the novel approach of expressing the Cdf in terms of generalized failure rate functions:

•a conditional forward hazard function, \$r_1\$,
•a conditional reverse hazard function, \$r_2\$;
.
For observed ordered failure-times, \$t_1 < t_2 < \cdots < t_k\$, [1]suggests estimators for \$r_1(t_i,\, t_j)\$ and \$r_2(t_i,\, t_j)\$ to plug into (1) to obtain the NPMLE of \$F\$.

When there is no censoring, [1] proposes to estimate \$r_1(t_i,\, t_j)\$ by the “number of failures at time \$t_i\$” divided by the “number of failures between \$t_i\$ and \$t_j\$, inclusive.” Similarly, \$r_2(t_i,\, t_j)\$ is estimated by the “number of failures at time \$t_j\$” divided by the “number of failures between \$t_i\$ and \$t_j\$, inclusive.” The resulting estimator of \$F\$ is the empirical Cdf.

To illustrate the deviation of the empirical Cdf estimator of \$F\$ [1] from the NPMLE when the data are truly doubly-truncated, consider a sample of 36 subjects with a common variant of “malignant brain tumor.” The subjects in this sample received chemotherapy, experienced progression of their tumors, and died of their disease.

It is of interest to use these data to estimate the Cdf of “time to progression” for the “population of subjects with this disease who progress.” Fig. 1 displays the estimator proposed in [1] (solid line) and the NPMLE computed using the algorithm from [3] (dashed line).

references.title: Failure-rate functions for doubly-truncated random variables
references.text: J. Navarro, J. M. Ruiz, "Failure-rate functions for doubly-truncated random variables", IEEE Trans. Rel., vol. 45, pp. 685-690, 1996.

context.text: For example, the times to progression for “patients with anaplastic oligodendroglioma (a common variant of malignant brain tumor) who received chemotherapy, experienced tumor progression, and subsequently died,” are doubly-truncated; the times to progression must exceed the “times to chemotherapy” and precede the “times to death.” In a quasar survey, apparent magnitude might be doubly-truncated by the investigator to avoid confusion with nonquasar stellar objects at the low end and to eliminate unreliable redshift measurements at the high end [2].

This is seen clearly from the expression [2] for the NPMLE of the unconditional forward hazard function 

Fig. 1.
The algorithm [3] is an alternative to the algorithm [2] which we have found to be more stable in small data sets.

references.title: Nonparametric methods for doubly truncated data
references.text: B. Efron, V. Petrosian, "Nonparametric methods for doubly truncated data", J. Amer. Statist. Assoc., vol. 94, pp. 824-834, 1999.

context.text: It is of interest to use these data to estimate the Cdf of “time to progression” for the “population of subjects with this disease who progress.” Fig. 1 displays the estimator proposed in [1] (solid line) and the NPMLE computed using the algorithm from [3] (dashed line).
The algorithm [3] is an alternative to the algorithm [2] which we have found to be more stable in small data sets.

references.title: The empirical distribution function with arbitrarily grouped, censored and truncated data
references.text: B. W. Turnbull, "The empirical distribution function with arbitrarily grouped censored and truncated data", J. R. Statist. Soc. B, vol. 38, pp. 290-295, 1976.

context.text: This follows immediately from the derivation of the NPMLE of the Sf for left-truncated data [4].

references.text: W.-Y. Tsai, N. P. Jewell, M.-C. Wang, "A note on the product-limit estimator under right censoring and left-truncation", Biometrika, vol. 74, pp. 883-886, 1987.
